definitions: A large amount of something.
A significant quantity or extent.
Considerably; much.
A substantial amount.
examples: He spent a good deal of time on that project.
It cost a good deal of money to repair the car.

definitions: A very large amount or extent.
To a very significant degree.
A lot; very much.
A substantial and notable quantity.
examples: She has a great deal of experience in marketing.
The situation has improved a great deal since last year.

definitions: The ability to appreciate or express what is amusing.
The quality of finding things funny and being able to make others laugh.
A capacity to perceive and enjoy what is comical.
The trait of being amusing or seeing amusement in situations.
examples: He has a great sense of humor and always makes me laugh.
A good sense of humor can help you cope with stress.

definitions: The power or skill to do something.
A talent or natural aptitude for an activity.
The means or skill to accomplish a task.
A person's capacity to perform an action.
examples: She has the ability to solve complex problems easily.
His athletic ability is very impressive for his age.

definitions: Not present in a place or at an occasion.
Missing from where one is expected to be.
Not in attendance.
Showing a lack of attention; distracted.
examples: He was absent from school yesterday due to illness.
Several key players were absent from the game.

definitions: Completely and without qualification; totally.
With no restriction or limitation.
Used to express strong agreement or confirmation.
Entirely; without a doubt.
examples: The movie was absolutely fantastic.
Are you sure you want to do this? Absolutely.

definitions: Existing in thought or as an idea but not having a physical existence.
Relating to art that does not try to represent external reality.
Not concrete or tangible.
Theoretical rather than practical.
examples: Love and freedom are abstract concepts.
She is a famous painter of abstract art.

definitions: Relating to education and scholarship.
Connected with a school, college, or university.
Not of practical relevance; only theoretical.
Scholarly and intellectual in nature.
examples: She has an excellent academic record.
The book is very academic and can be difficult to read.

definitions: To consent to receive or undertake something offered.
To say 'yes' to an offer or invitation.
To willingly take something that is given to you.
To agree to a proposal or suggestion.
examples: He accepted the job offer immediately.
Please accept this gift as a token of my gratitude.

definitions: To admit that something is true, valid, or correct.
To acknowledge responsibility or blame for something.
To come to terms with a difficult or unpleasant situation.
To recognize the reality of something.
examples: You must accept the consequences of your actions.
He refused to accept that he had made a mistake.

definitions: A place to live, work, or stay in.
Lodging, especially for a temporary period.
A room or building for someone to live in.
A place providing shelter for travelers.
examples: The price of the holiday includes flights and accommodation.
Student accommodation is hard to find in this city.

definitions: To perform a part in a play or film.
To behave in a particular way.
Something that is done; a deed.
A main division of a play or opera.
examples: She has acted in several successful movies.
It's important to act responsibly.

definitions: Engaging in energetic or busy pursuits.
Involving movement and physical effort.
Working or in operation.
Taking part in something; participating.
examples: It's important to stay active as you get older.
She is an active member of the local community.

definitions: Existing in fact; real.
True and not imagined or supposed.
Used to emphasize that a situation exists.
Being in existence as a fact, not just an idea.
examples: The actual cost of the project was much higher than we expected.
What were his actual words?

definitions: To become adjusted to new conditions.
To modify something for a new use or purpose.
To change your behavior to suit a new situation.
To alter something to make it suitable for new circumstances.
examples: It took him a while to adapt to his new life in the city.
The movie is adapted from a famous novel.

definitions: To legally take another's child and bring it up as one's own.
To choose to take up or follow an idea, method, or course of action.
To begin to use a new approach or style.
To formally approve or accept a proposal.
examples: They are unable to have children of their own, so they decided to adopt.
The company adopted a new policy on remote work.

definitions: A business or organization providing a particular service.
A government department or administrative unit.
A company that acts on behalf of other people or companies.
An establishment that provides a professional service.
examples: She found her new job through an employment agency.
The travel agency helped us plan our vacation.

definitions: Further forward in space or time.
In front.
In advance; before an event happens.
Making more progress than others.
examples: The road ahead was blocked by a fallen tree.
She is far ahead of the other students in her class.

definitions: Help or support given to someone in need.
Assistance, especially in the form of money or resources.
Something that helps you to do a task.
To provide support or help to someone.
examples: The country received a lot of foreign aid after the earthquake.
A hearing aid can help people with hearing loss.

definitions: Any vehicle that can fly, such as an airplane or helicopter.
A machine capable of flight through the air.
An airplane or any other machine that can fly.
A flying vehicle.
examples: The airport handles hundreds of aircraft every day.
He is learning to fly a small aircraft.

definitions: In a similar way.
Similar to each other.
Resembling one another.
In the same or a comparable manner.
examples: The two brothers look very much alike.
Great minds think alike.

definitions: Throughout the entire day.
From morning until night.
Continuously during the day.
For the whole day without stopping.
examples: He was working in the garden all day long.
The baby cried all day long.

definitions: Arranged in the order of the letters of the alphabet.
In the sequence of A, B, C, and so on.
Organized by letter.
In alphabetic order.
examples: The names on the list are in alphabetical order.
Please arrange these files in alphabetical order.

definitions: One of two or more available possibilities.
A different option or choice.
Another possibility that you can choose.
A choice between two or more things.
examples: Is there a cheaper alternative to this medicine?
We have no alternative but to cancel the event.

definitions: A spiritual being believed to be a messenger of God.
A very kind and good person.
A celestial being, often depicted with wings.
A being with supernatural powers.
examples: The story was about an angel who came down to Earth.
You are an angel for helping me so much with this.

definitions: The date on which an event took place in a previous year.
The yearly recurrence of a specific date.
A celebration of a past event on the same day each year.
A yearly commemoration of an event.
examples: They are celebrating their 25th wedding anniversary.
Tomorrow is the anniversary of his passing.

definitions: Occurring once every year.
Relating to a year or happening on a yearly basis.
Calculated over a period of a year.
Happening once a year.
examples: The company holds an annual conference for its employees.
What is your annual salary?

definitions: Used to emphasize a negative statement; at all.
Used to refer to one or some of a thing, no matter how much.
In the slightest degree.
Even a little.
examples: I don't feel any better today.
He won't eat any of his vegetables.

definitions: In any case; regardless of other considerations.
Used to change the subject or end a conversation.
Despite the situation; nevertheless.
In a careless or untidy way.
examples: It's too late to go out now, anyhow.
Anyhow, let's talk about something more pleasant.

definitions: Separated by a distance.
Into pieces or parts.
Not together; separately.
Aside from.
examples: The two houses are about a mile apart.
He took the engine apart to fix it.

definitions: To come into sight; to become visible.
To seem to be a certain way.
To present oneself in public, especially as a performer.
To become noticeable.
examples: A man suddenly appeared from behind the corner.
She will be appearing in a new movie next year.

definitions: A program or piece of software designed for a particular purpose.
A computer program for a specific task.
A formal request for something, like a job.
Commonly known as an 'app'.
examples: You can download the application from the app store.
This is a very useful application for editing photos on your phone.

definitions: To make a formal request for something, such as a job or a place at a university.
To be relevant to a particular case or person.
To put a substance onto a surface.
To use a particular method or idea.
examples: I'm going to apply for that job vacancy.
This rule doesn't apply to new members.

definitions: To recognize the full worth of something.
To be grateful for something that someone has done.
To understand a situation and its implications fully.
To value something highly.
examples: I really appreciate all your help.
He doesn't appreciate the value of a good education.

definitions: To come near or nearer to someone or something in distance or time.
The act of coming closer.
A way of dealing with something.
To get closer to a place or person.
examples: The train is now approaching the station.
As winter approached, the days grew shorter.

definitions: To officially agree to or accept as satisfactory.
To have a positive opinion of someone or something.
To authorize or sanction.
To consent to something.
examples: The committee approved the new budget.
My parents don't approve of my decision.

definitions: A person who designs buildings and supervises their construction.
Someone who plans the design of buildings and structures.
A building designer.
A person who conceives and plans a large project.
examples: He is a famous architect who designed many well-known buildings.
We hired an architect to design our new home.

definitions: A subject or range of activity or interest.
A particular field of study or knowledge.
A region or part of a town or country.
A specific part of knowledge or activity.
examples: He is an expert in the area of computer science.
This is a very interesting area of research.

definitions: To put things in a neat, attractive, or required order.
To plan or make preparations for a future event.
To organize things in a systematic way.
To set up or schedule something.
examples: She arranged the flowers beautifully in a vase.
I've arranged a meeting for tomorrow morning.

definitions: To seize someone by legal authority and take them into custody.
The action of seizing someone to take them into custody.
To stop or check the progress of something.
To capture and hold by legal authority.
examples: The police arrested him for the robbery.
He was placed under arrest for two days.

definitions: A particular part or feature of something.
A specific facet of a situation or problem.
A characteristic or quality.
A point of view to consider.
examples: We need to consider all aspects of the problem before making a decision.
The book covers every aspect of the topic in detail.

definitions: To evaluate or estimate the nature, ability, or quality of something.
To judge the value or importance of something.
To calculate the value of property or income for taxation purposes.
To appraise or judge.
examples: The teacher will assess the students' performance at the end of the year.
It's difficult to assess the impact of the new policy.

definitions: Finally; after a long time or delay.
At the end of a period of waiting.
Eventually, after much anticipation.
After much delay.
examples: At last, the rain has stopped.
He has found a job at long last.

definitions: A person who is proficient in sports and other forms of physical exercise.
A person who competes in sports events.
A sportsman or sportswoman.
Someone who is skilled in athletics.
examples: He is a professional athlete who competes internationally.
The Olympic athletes are training for the games.

definitions: To join or fasten something to something else.
To include a file with an email message.
To connect one thing to another.
To ascribe importance or value to.
examples: Please attach a recent photograph to your application form.
I've attached the report to this email for you to review.

definitions: To make an effort to achieve or complete something difficult.
An act of trying to do something.
To try to accomplish a task.
An endeavor or effort.
examples: He attempted to break the world record, but failed.
It was a good attempt, even though she didn't succeed.

definitions: To be present at an event, meeting, or function.
To go regularly to a place such as a school or church.
To deal with something.
To be at an event.
examples: Are you going to attend the conference next week?
The meeting was attended by over 500 people.

definitions: The power or right to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience.
A person or organization having power or control in a particular sphere.
An expert on a subject.
The power to influence others based on a position.
examples: He has the authority to make the final decision.
The local authorities are responsible for maintaining the roads.

definitions: An icon or figure representing a particular person in a video game, on the internet, etc.
A digital representation of a user.
A graphical image that represents a person in a virtual world.
A user's virtual persona.
examples: He chose a dragon as his avatar in the online game.
You can customize your avatar's appearance with different clothes.

definitions: A prize or other mark of recognition given in honor of an achievement.
To give something officially as a prize or reward.
An honor or distinction.
To bestow a prize upon someone.
examples: She won an award for her latest novel.
He was awarded a medal for his bravery.

definitions: Very bad or unpleasant.
Terrible.
Extremely bad or of poor quality.
Used to emphasize a large amount (informal).
examples: The weather was awful all weekend.
I feel awful about what happened.

definitions: To look after a child or children while the parents are out.
To care for children temporarily as a job.
To act as a childminder.
To supervise children for a short time.
examples: She babysits for her neighbors every Friday night.
Can you babysit for us tonight?

definitions: An even distribution of weight enabling someone or something to remain upright and steady.
To keep in a steady position without falling.
A state of equilibrium.
To offset two things so they are equal.
examples: It's difficult to keep your balance on a moving boat.
She managed to balance the book on her head.

definitions: A strip of material used to bind up a wound or injury.
A dressing for a wound to protect it.
To bind a wound with a strip of cloth.
A protective covering for an injury.
examples: The nurse put a bandage on his cut finger.
He had a bandage wrapped around his head.

definitions: A person who cuts men's hair and shaves or trims beards as an occupation.
A men's hairdresser.
A person whose trade is cutting hair and shaving.
A men's hairstylist.
examples: He went to the barber to get a haircut.
My barber always tells the best stories.

definitions: The lowest part or edge of something, especially the part on which it rests.
The bottom support of anything.
A military headquarters.
The main ingredient of something.
examples: The statue has a large marble base.
We started our climb from the base of the mountain.

definitions: Forming an essential foundation; fundamental.
Simple and not elaborate.
Of a primary or elementary level.
Essential and straightforward.
examples: He has a basic understanding of the subject.
The hotel provides basic accommodation for travelers.

definitions: A bowl for washing, typically attached to a wall in a bathroom.
A round, open container, especially for liquids.
A large, low-lying area of land, often with a river.
A sink.
examples: He washed his hands in the basin.
The Amazon basin is a vast and important region.

definitions: The underlying foundation or principle for an idea, argument, or process.
The main reason for something.
A starting point for a system.
A foundation.
examples: What is the basis for your conclusion?
The agreement will form the basis of our future cooperation.

definitions: An edible seed, typically kidney-shaped, growing in long pods on certain plants.
A type of legume used as a vegetable.
The seed of a coffee plant.
A plant that produces pods with seeds.
examples: I like to eat baked beans on toast.
Green beans are a very healthy vegetable.

definitions: Someone you do not know.
An unfamiliar person.
An individual with whom one is not acquainted.
A person who is new to a place.
examples: It is not always safe to talk to a stranger.
A kind stranger helped me find my way when I was lost.

definitions: A very large amount of money.
An abundance of wealth or assets.
A substantial sum of money and riches.
A great deal of financial resources.
examples: That antique vase is worth a fortune.
He made a fortune by investing in technology stocks.

definitions: Someone who is in charge of a school.
The head of an elementary, middle, or high school.
The lead administrator of a school.
The person with the highest authority in a school.
examples: The principal gave an announcement over the loudspeaker.
I have a meeting with the principal tomorrow afternoon.

definitions: Relating to money.
Connected with the management of money and finance.
Pertaining to monetary matters.
Involving finance and money.
examples: The company is facing serious financial difficulties.
He works as a financial advisor.

definitions: Very unusual or surprising.
Beyond what is ordinary or regular.
Remarkable and amazing.
Highly exceptional.
examples: She has an extraordinary talent for music.
The view from the mountaintop was extraordinary.

definitions: Not cooked.
In its natural state; unprocessed.
Not yet prepared for eating.
Uncooked food.
examples: Sushi is made with raw fish.
It is not safe to eat raw chicken.

definitions: To hurry or move quickly.
To do something with great speed.
To act with haste.
To move with urgency.
examples: We had to rush to catch the train.
Don't rush your work or you will make mistakes.

definitions: To entertain people by acting or singing.
To present a play, concert, or other form of entertainment to an audience.
To do something to amuse an audience.
To execute a performance.
examples: The band will perform live at the festival.
She loves to perform on stage.

definitions: To not have enough of something.
To be without or be deficient in.
To have an insufficient quantity of something.
To be in need of something that is missing.
examples: The project failed because it lacked funding.
He lacks the confidence to speak in public.

definitions: Hardly; by the narrowest margin.
Only just; almost not.
In a minimal or scant way.
With difficulty.
examples: I could barely hear him over the loud music.
She was so tired she could barely keep her eyes open.

definitions: Recently; in the near past.
In the time just before the present.
Not long ago.
Of late.
examples: Have you seen any good movies lately?
I haven't been feeling very well lately.

definitions: Usually; in most situations.
Mainly or for the most part.
By or to most people.
As a general rule.
examples: Generally, I prefer to work in the morning.
The new policy was generally well received.

definitions: To say that you are not willing to do something.
To indicate that one is unwilling to accept or grant something.
To decline an offer or request.
To show unwillingness to do something.
examples: He refused to answer any more questions.
She refused my offer of help.

definitions: To persuade someone to do something or to believe something.
To cause someone to feel certain about something.
To make someone agree with your viewpoint.
To win someone over to your opinion.
examples: I tried to convince him to stay, but he left anyway.
She managed to convince the committee to approve her proposal.

definitions: To expect something to happen.
To regard as probable; to look forward to.
To foresee and prepare for a future event.
To act in advance of something.
examples: We anticipate that the new product will be very successful.
It is impossible to anticipate every problem.

definitions: Quick and unexpected.
Happening or done quickly and without warning.
Abrupt.
Not expected.
examples: There was a sudden change in the weather.
His sudden departure surprised everyone.

definitions: Reasonable and having good judgment.
Practical and based on good sense.
Showing wisdom and prudence.
Not foolish or impractical.
examples: That was a very sensible decision.
She is a sensible and reliable person.

definitions: Extremely important or necessary.
Decisive or critical, especially for success or failure.
Of great importance.
Essential for a particular outcome.
examples: It is crucial that we act immediately.
The next few weeks will be crucial for the project.

definitions: A manager of a company or an organization.
A person who is in charge of an activity or department.
A member of the board of a company.
The person who supervises a film or play.
examples: She was appointed as the new director of the company.
He is the director of the marketing department.

definitions: An improvement or a development in something.
A forward movement or progress.
A step forward in a particular field.
A new development.
examples: There have been great advances in medical technology.
This discovery is a major advance in science.

definitions: Something you say to show you are sorry for doing something wrong.
A regretful acknowledgment of an offense or failure.
An expression of regret for a mistake.
A statement saying you are sorry.
examples: He offered her a sincere apology.
I think you owe him an apology.

definitions: Far from places where most people live.
Distant in space or time.
Situated far from the main centers of population.
Having very little connection with or relationship to.
examples: They live in a remote village in the mountains.
There is a remote chance of success.

definitions: Difficult to believe; extraordinary.
Extremely good or impressive.
Astonishing.
Almost impossible to believe.
examples: The view from the top was incredible.
He told an incredible story of his survival.

definitions: Having a natural ability to do something well.
Showing a special skill or aptitude.
Gifted in a particular area.
Possessing a natural talent.
examples: She is a very talented musician.
He is a talented artist with a bright future.

definitions: To travel to a foreign country.
To go to a different country, especially for a vacation or work.
To journey internationally.
To leave one's own country for another.
examples: I would love to go abroad for a year.
He is going abroad on business next week.

definitions: To relax and not worry or work too hard.
To proceed in a calm and leisurely manner.
To not overexert oneself.
To rest and avoid stress.
examples: You've been working too hard; you should take it easy.
Take it easy, there's no need to panic.

definitions: To draw pictures for a book, magazine, etc.
To provide a book with pictures.
To make something clear with examples.
To serve as an example of.
examples: The author decided to illustrate the book himself.
This chart will illustrate the company's growth.

definitions: To do what you are told to do.
To comply with a command, direction, or request.
To follow a rule or law.
To submit to the authority of someone.
examples: You must obey the rules of the school.
The dog was trained to obey simple commands.

definitions: To know who someone is because you have seen them before.
To identify someone or something from previous encounters.
To acknowledge the existence or validity of something.
To accept something as valid.
examples: I didn't recognize you with your new haircut.
The government has refused to recognize the new regime.

definitions: Most of the people or things in a group.
The greater number or part of a whole.
More than half of the total.
The winning number of votes in an election.
examples: The majority of students voted against the proposal.
A large majority of the population supports the new law.

definitions: The time when you are free from work and can relax.
Free time used for enjoyment.
Recreational time.
Time off from one's job.
examples: What do you do in your leisure time?
The hotel offers many leisure facilities, such as a pool and a gym.

definitions: A religious or social event that includes certain traditional actions.
A formal event held on a special occasion.
A set of formal acts for a public or religious event.
A rite or ritual.
examples: The wedding ceremony was beautiful.
He attended the graduation ceremony.

definitions: Adequate; good enough.
Fulfilling expectations or needs.
Acceptable, but not outstanding.
Meeting a required standard.
examples: His work was satisfactory but not exceptional.
We have not yet found a satisfactory solution to the problem.

definitions: From a long time ago; belonging to the very distant past.
Very old.
From an early period of history.
Having existed for a great while.
examples: We visited the ancient ruins of a Roman city.
This is an ancient tradition that is still practiced today.

definitions: Without a job.
Not having paid employment but available to work.
Out of work.
Jobless.
examples: He has been unemployed for six months.
The government has a program to help unemployed people.

definitions: In the past; in an earlier period.
Previously.
At an earlier time.
Before the present time.
examples: The building was formerly a school.
She was formerly known as an actress.

definitions: Not exactly; approximately.
In a way that is not precise.
More or less.
In a harsh or violent way.
examples: There were roughly 50 people at the meeting.
The journey will take roughly two hours.

definitions: Possibly; with a chance of happening.
Used to express that something may happen.
As a possibility.
In a way that could develop in the future.
examples: This is a potentially dangerous situation.
The new drug is potentially very effective.

definitions: To remove something from a place.
To subtract a number.
To get food from a restaurant to eat elsewhere.
To cause something to disappear.
examples: Please take away the dirty plates.
If you take 3 away from 10, you get 7.

definitions: Actually; in reality.
Used to add emphasis to a statement.
In fact.
A phrase to introduce a surprising or correcting piece of information.
examples: He seems shy, but as a matter of fact, he's very talkative.
As a matter of fact, I was just about to call you.

definitions: Before a particular time, or before doing something.
Ahead of time.
Beforehand.
In anticipation of a future event.
examples: You need to book your tickets in advance.
Thank you in advance for your help.

definitions: An angry disagreement between two or more people.
A heated argument or dispute.
A verbal conflict.
To have an angry disagreement.
examples: They had a bitter quarrel about money.
I don't want to have a quarrel with you.

definitions: Money that is not spent but kept for use in the future.
The money a person has saved, especially in a bank.
An economy of or reduction in money or time.
Reserved funds.
examples: He used all his savings to buy a new car.
It's important to have some savings for emergencies.

definitions: Someone who is paid to work for a person, a company, or an organization.
A person who works for another in return for wages.
A member of a company's staff.
A worker.
examples: The company has over 500 employees.
He is a loyal and hardworking employee.

definitions: Completely different.
Situated on the other side of a space.
The contrary of something.
Facing in a contrary direction.
examples: We have opposite opinions on this subject.
The bank is on the opposite side of the street.

definitions: Perfect or most suitable.
Satisfying one's conception of what is best.
Existing only in the imagination.
Most appropriate for a purpose.
examples: This is an ideal location for a picnic.
She is the ideal candidate for the job.

definitions: Willing to give money or spend time helping others.
Showing a readiness to give more of something than is expected.
Larger or more plentiful than is usual.
Kind and giving.
examples: It was very generous of you to lend me the money.
He made a generous donation to the charity.

definitions: To leave one's job, usually because of old age.
To stop working permanently.
To withdraw from one's position or occupation.
To go to bed.
examples: He plans to retire next year at the age of 65.
She retired from teaching after 40 years.

definitions: To try very hard to do something difficult.
To make forceful or violent efforts to get free of restraint.
To have difficulty handling or coping with something.
To contend with an opponent.
examples: She struggled to lift the heavy box.
The company is struggling to survive in the current market.

definitions: To reply or say something as a reaction.
To act in response to something that has happened.
To answer.
To show a reaction to a stimulus.
examples: He didn't respond to my question.
How did she respond to the news?

definitions: In fact; in reality.
Used to emphasize that something is true.
As a matter of fact.
Used to express surprise.
examples: He seems shy, but he's actually very talkative.
I didn't actually see him, I just heard his voice.

definitions: Probably will happen or is expected.
Such as well might happen or be true; probable.
Seeming to be true.
In all probability.
examples: It's likely to rain later today.
She is the most likely candidate to win.

definitions: For a very long time or forever.
In a way that lasts or remains unchanged indefinitely.
Not temporarily.
For all time.
examples: The accident left him permanently disabled.
She has decided to move to Canada permanently.

definitions: Immediately; without delay.
At once.
Straight away.
Without waiting.
examples: I'll do it right away.
Please call me back right away.

definitions: Certainly; without any doubt.
Definitely.
Unquestionably.
For certain.
examples: I know for sure that he was there.
Are you coming to the party? For sure!

definitions: A large amount of money that a person has.
An abundance of valuable possessions or money.
The state of being rich.
A plentiful supply of a particular resource.
examples: He acquired his wealth through wise investments.
The country has a wealth of natural resources.

definitions: Help or advice, often given to help deal with a problem.
The act of directing or showing the way.
Advice on what to do.
Leadership or direction.
examples: I'm looking for some career guidance.
He needs the guidance of a good mentor.

definitions: A meeting arranged for a particular time.
A formal arrangement to meet or visit someone.
The act of assigning a job or position.
A scheduled meeting.
examples: I have an appointment with the doctor at 10 a.m.
She had to cancel her appointment.

definitions: Something that is found or learned about for the first time.
The action of finding something new.
An act of finding something unexpected.
A revelation.
examples: The discovery of penicillin revolutionized medicine.
He made an important scientific discovery.

definitions: A shopping center.
A large indoor complex containing a variety of stores.

There were a few problems, but on the whole, it was a successful event.

definitions: In order to.
With the result or purpose that.
For the purpose of.
With the intention that.
examples: I'm studying hard so that I can pass the exam.
Speak louder so that everyone can hear you.

definitions: Before.
In front of someone or something.
Further forward in time or space.
In advance of.
examples: She finished the race ahead of all the other runners.
We have a lot of work ahead of us.

definitions: All the people living in a particular area, city, or country.
The total number of inhabitants of a place.
A particular group of people.
The community of people in a region.
examples: What is the population of China?
The world's population is increasing rapidly.

definitions: A separate part of something, such as of a book.
Any of the distinct parts into which something is divided.
A division of an area or object.
A segment.
examples: I read the first section of the report.
The store has a large electronics section.

definitions: Changing something that is spoken or written into another language.
The process of converting words from one language to another.
A written or spoken rendering of the meaning of a word in another language.
An interpretation.
examples: The book is available in an English translation.
She works in translation.

definitions: To bring something to someone's address.
To take goods, letters, or parcels to people's houses or places of work.
To give a speech or formal statement.
To provide something promised.
examples: The postman delivers the mail every morning.
The company will deliver the furniture tomorrow.

definitions: To watch something carefully.
To notice or perceive something and register it as being significant.
To monitor.
To see and pay attention to.
examples: Scientists observe the behavior of animals in the wild.
I observed that he was acting strangely.

definitions: To work together for a particular purpose.
To act jointly with another or others.
To assist someone willingly.
To collaborate.
examples: The two countries agreed to cooperate on the project.
We need everyone to cooperate to get this done.

definitions: Easy to notice or to understand.
Clearly perceived; plain to see.
Not difficult to comprehend.
Evident.
examples: It was obvious that she was unhappy.
For obvious reasons, we can't go.

definitions: Unusual or unexpected.
Difficult to understand or explain.
Not familiar.
Peculiar.
examples: I heard a strange noise last night.
He's been acting very strange lately.

definitions: Having the ability to do something well.
Having or showing the knowledge, ability, or training to perform a certain activity.
Expert at a particular task.
Proficient.
examples: She is a highly skilled surgeon.
We need a skilled worker for this job.

definitions: A plan of what you are going to do and when you will do it.
A timetable.
A program of events.
To plan an event for a particular time.
examples: My schedule is very busy this week.
What is the schedule for today's events?

definitions: Something that happens, especially something important.
A planned public or social occasion.
An occurrence.
An item in a sports program.
examples: The wedding was a memorable event.
The conference is a major annual event.

definitions: A large area of land.
An area having definable characteristics but not always fixed boundaries.
A particular part of a country or the world.
A district.
examples: This region is famous for its wine.
The northern region of the country is mountainous.

definitions: To be responsible for something or someone.
To have control over a person, group, or task.
To be the leader of.
To manage.
examples: She is in charge of the entire project.
Who is in charge here?

definitions: To think about something carefully.
To take something into account before making a decision.
To have an opinion about someone or something.
To contemplate.
examples: I'm considering a job offer.
We need to consider all the options.

definitions: To stop something from happening.
To keep an event or action from occurring.
To hinder or obstruct.
To make something impossible.
examples: The new measures are intended to prevent crime.
He tried to prevent me from leaving.

definitions: A result of something that has happened.
An effect or outcome of an action.
Importance or relevance.
An aftermath.
examples: He must face the consequences of his actions.
The accident was a tragic consequence of his carelessness.

definitions: Something that is difficult to achieve.
A task or situation that tests someone's abilities.
An invitation to compete.
A difficult task.
examples: Learning a new language is a real challenge.
She loves a good challenge.

definitions: A chance to do something.
A favorable time or set of circumstances for doing something.
A good occasion.
A possibility to achieve something.
examples: This is a great opportunity to start a new career.
Don't miss this opportunity.

definitions: In the correct way.
Satisfactorily or correctly.
Appropriately.
Rightly.
examples: Make sure you do the job properly.
The machine is not working properly.

definitions: Sometimes; from time to time.
Now and then.
Infrequently.
On some occasions.
examples: I see him occasionally.
We occasionally go out for dinner.

definitions: Something or someone that is well known to you.
Having a good knowledge of something.
Commonly seen or heard.
Informal and friendly.
examples: His face looks familiar.
Are you familiar with this author?

definitions: Something that can be seen.
Able to be perceived by the eye.
Apparent.
Noticeable.
examples: The mountains were visible in the distance.
There was a visible change in her mood.

definitions: Something that can be trusted to work well.
Consistently good in quality or performance.
Dependable.
Trustworthy.
examples: This is a reliable car.
He is a very reliable employee.

definitions: To continue doing something.
To proceed with an activity.
To not stop.
To behave in an excited or silly way.
examples: Please carry on with your work.
She decided to carry on despite the difficulties.

definitions: To find something by chance.
To meet someone accidentally.
To seem to be a particular type of person.
To encounter unexpectedly.
examples: I came across an old photo while cleaning my room.
She comes across as a very confident person.

definitions: Amount.
The number of something.
A certain amount.
A large number.
examples: We need a large quantity of food for the party.
Quality is more important than quantity.

definitions: No sound.
A complete absence of noise.
To make someone or something quiet.
The state of being quiet.
examples: A complete silence fell over the room.
I need silence to concentrate.

definitions: To refuse to accept something.
To not accept a proposal or offer.
To dismiss as inadequate.
To turn down.
examples: He rejected her offer of help.
The committee rejected the proposal.

definitions: To allow someone to do something.
To give permission for an action.
To authorize.
An official document giving permission.
examples: Smoking is not permitted in this building.
The rules do not permit guests after midnight.

definitions: To try to do something.
To make an effort to achieve something difficult.
An effort to do something.
To endeavor.
examples: He attempted to break the world record.
She will attempt to climb the mountain.

definitions: Important; worthy of attention.
Sufficiently great or important.
Having a particular meaning.
Notable.
examples: There has been a significant increase in prices.
This is a significant moment in our history.

definitions: Without any errors.
Correct in all details; exact.
Precise.
Free from mistakes.
examples: The report is accurate.
He gave an accurate description of the event.

definitions: Something you can choose not to do.
Available to be chosen but not obligatory.
Not compulsory.
Left to one's choice.
examples: Attendance at the meeting is optional.
The extra features are optional.

definitions: Usually.
Under normal or typical conditions.
In a regular way.
As a rule.
examples: I normally go to bed at 11 PM.
The bus is normally on time.

definitions: Before the present time.
At an earlier time.
Formerly.
In the past.
examples: He was previously the CEO of the company.
I have seen this movie previously.

definitions: For a short time.
In a few words; concisely.
In a concise manner.
For a brief period.
examples: He spoke briefly about his new book.
I'll be back briefly.

definitions: To think about something until you understand it.
To solve a problem.
To come to understand.
To decipher.
examples: I can't figure out how to solve this puzzle.
We need to figure out a better way.

definitions: To begin doing something new.
To become interested in a new activity.
To occupy time or space.
To start a new hobby.
examples: I've decided to take up painting.
This new project will take up a lot of my time.

definitions: To be made up of something.
To be composed of.
To have as its parts.
To comprise.
examples: The team consists of five members.
The book consists of three main parts.

definitions: To provide people with something they need or want.
To make something available.
To furnish with.
A stock of a resource.
examples: The company supplies electricity to the city.
We can supply you with all the information you need.

definitions: To advise someone to do something.
To suggest something as being good or suitable.
To endorse.
To put forward with approval.
examples: Can you recommend a good restaurant?
I would recommend that you see a doctor.

definitions: To believe that something might be true.
To suppose to be the case, without proof.
To take for granted.
To take on a responsibility.
examples: I assume you're coming to the party.
Let's assume his story is true.

definitions: Eventually; over a long period of time.
Ultimately.
In the future.
After a long time.
examples: It may seem difficult now, but it will be worth it in the long run.
In the long run, we need to find a better solution.

definitions: Can no longer be used; old-fashioned.
No longer valid or current.
Obsolete.
Not up-to-date.
examples: This information is out of date.
His ideas are a bit out of date.

definitions: Sometimes.
Occasionally.
Now and then.
Infrequently.
examples: I see him from time to time.
From time to time, I like to go for a walk.

definitions: Someone who travels on a bus or a train.
A traveler in a vehicle, but not the driver.
A person who is conveyed in a vehicle.
A traveler.
examples: The bus was full of passengers.
All passengers must have a valid ticket.

definitions: To make a new type of thing.
To create or design something that has not existed before.
To make up a false story.
To fabricate.
examples: Who invented the telephone?
He invented an excuse for being late.

definitions: To ask for something.
To politely or formally ask for something.
An act of asking for something.
To demand.
examples: I'd like to request a meeting with you.
He requested more information.

definitions: To say something will happen in the future.
To forecast.
To make a statement about a future event.
To foretell.
examples: It's difficult to predict the future.
They predicted that the company would fail.

definitions: An idea you ask someone to think about.
A proposal or recommendation.
An idea put forward for consideration.
A hint or trace of something.
examples: Do you have any suggestions?
I have a suggestion for you.

definitions: A way of life common to a group of people.
A long-established custom or belief.
A belief or behavior passed down within a group.
A convention.
examples: It's a family tradition to have a big dinner on Sundays.
This is an ancient tradition.

definitions: Something that other people don't know about.
Something that is kept unknown or unseen by others.
Confidential information.
A mystery.
examples: Can you keep a secret?
The meeting was held in secret.

definitions: To stop trying to do something.
To cease making an effort; to surrender.
To quit a habit.
To abandon an attempt.
examples: Don't give up on your dreams.
He gave up smoking last year.

definitions: To start a journey.
To begin a trip or course of action.
To embark on a journey.
To arrange or display things.
examples: They set out on their adventure early in the morning.
He set out to break the world record.
